title: 113_hr5497
content: The "Film Incentive Reform Act of 2014" allows for the modification and extension of the election to expense the cost of qualified film, television, and theatrical productions. The "Film Incentive Reform Act of 2014" extends the deadline to December 31, 2015, for the election to expense the cost of qualified film, television, and theatrical productions. The amendment also specifies the criteria for a production to be considered qualified. The total compensation of the theatrical production is qualified compensation. The term 'theatrical production' refers to a live staged production of a play derived from a written book. The text chunk discusses the criteria for a live staged production to qualify as a theatrical production for tax purposes, including audience capacity and touring company considerations. The text chunk outlines the phases and qualified compensation criteria for live staged productions to qualify as theatrical productions for tax purposes. The text chunk defines 'compensation' for services in the United States by various personnel in film, television, and theatrical productions, excluding participations and residuals. It also excludes productions requiring records under section 2257 of title 18, United States Code. The text chunk amends sections of the Code to include theatrical productions in addition to film and television productions. The item for section 181 in the Code is amended to include theatrical productions. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified film, television, and theatrical productions starting after December 31, 2013.
